Award.AwardTitle: CyberSEES: Type 2: Collaborative Research: A Computational and Analytic Laboratory for Modeling and Predicting Marine Biodiversity and Indicators of Sustainable Ecosystems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Marine ecosystems are complex and variable networks of interacting organisms that support roughly half of global productivity and play important roles in sustaining global processes. The lower trophic levels that are the focus of this project include primary producers at the base of the food web, as well as bacteria and a variety of small grazers that turn over rapidly and provide links that transfer energy to higher trophic levels, such as fish, seabirds, and marine mammals, helping to maintain healthy ecosystems. Mounting recognition points to the societal value of not just timely information about the status and change of marine ecosystems but how well we can model and predict them. While existing and emerging observation systems are poised to contribute, there is a large need for computationally-enabled marine biodiversity data and information systems. Despite recognition as system-level science, the way specialists and non-specialists think about ecosystems must move from reducing the problem spaces into specialized and finer partitions to a significantly more integrative and predictive one. This research effort brings together computational and information scientists, oceanographers and microbiologists to develop a Marine Biodiversity Virtual Laboratory (MBVL). In addition to research investigations of marine ecosystems, the Virtual Laboratory provides a platform for education via student diversity programs at the three institutions. The important learning opportunities will be two-fold for students: (1) to learn about, model, and make predictions for biodiversity in natural systems, and (2) to be exposed to working in an interdisciplinary team that includes both natural scientists and computer scientists. The project aims to foster a new generation of data scientists with skills that can cross disciplines. There will be capabilities to trace, verify and trust the original data and model sources that comprise key indicators of diversity as part of ecosystem health; this has become a requirement for technical (and societal) implementations. MBVL will contain a knowledge base for such indicators. While this is essential for research, the MBVL will also enhance education as students will truly probe, question, explore and experiment with the health, risks, and possible changes in specific marine environments.

MBVL will address multi-scale, heterogeneous data challenges with informatics solutions that enable the cyber-generation and documentation of biodiversity indicators, providing the traceability between data and information to be used as a basis for sustainable ecosystem-based management and needed policy decisions. Thus researchers and students will be further engaged to think and act at the system-level. The research will have impacts beyond ocean sciences, i.e. more broadly in management and policymaking regarding marine resources and ecosystem services via key links with fisheries managers enabled by collaborations external to this project and with industry partners to evaluate and disseminate solutions to a much wider user base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together computational and information scientists, oceanographers and microbiologists to develop a Marine Biodiversity Virtual Laboratory. We enabled transformative access to and integration of ocean observations to produce new knowledge about marine ecosystems and the services they provide. In the field of biological oceanography, the results of this project are enabling new ways to undertake biodiversity research. High volume data sets such as result from genetic sequencing, automated flow cytometry, and automated imaging will not reach their full potential without use-case driven solutions to big data challenges. We addressed research objectives including data access, data products, use cases to test software development, and traceable workflows. Broader impacts of the research included education and workforce development and engaging with national agency partnerships, international working groups, and industry.

In particular we targeted image data for phytoplankton as one of the data types to hit the "3 V's of Big Data" - Variety, Velocity, and Volume. One of the data sets that we worked with is from an underwater microscope - an Imaging FlowCytobot (IFCB). IFCB has been deployed at an observatory off the coast of Martha?s Vineyard, MA, collecting images of phytoplankton every 20 minutes for 15 years, as well as on 35 research cruises surveying the Northeast U.S. Shelf ecosystem in different seasons since 2013. As of December 2020 we have over a billion images in this data set. To gain information about this many images - such as what species and sizes of plankton are there - required the development of machine learning and other software to automatically classify and measure the images. 

We also developed a data model to contribute IFCB data products to community repositories addressing Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR) principles. The data model, and our conceptual workflow to populate it, will have impact not only for this data type but for the interoperability of other taxon-resolved data between community repositories and global aggregators such as the Ocean Biodiversity Information System. We are now well positioned to implement automated methods for contributing data products from plankton imaging systems into global biodiversity data systems.

The project addressed data challenges with informatics solutions that included traceable workflows to enable the cyber-generation and documentation of biodiversity indicators. We shared these solutions at national and international workshops and conferences, in journal articles, and online code repositories. Use cases for these workflows included spatial maps of phytoplankton imaged continuously underway during research cruises, to validate satellite ocean color data products and to be used as a basis for sustainable ecosystem-based management and needed policy decisions. Direct economic value is associated with relatively few marine species that are harvested for food or other natural resources, but the sustainability of marine ecosystems and their many services depends critically on a much wider diversity of smaller life forms. Sustaining the health and services provided by marine ecosystems has high societal value, and biodiversity is an important metric.   

Beyond the ocean sciences, we anticipate impacts in biodiversity science more broadly inclusive of Earth systems, important for the Group On Earth Observations Biodiversity Observation Network Essential Biodiversity Variables. Outcomes of this project will also be promoted through the newly-established, nation-wide Earth Science Information Partners working group to promote best practices for the sharing of biodiversity and associated environmental data.

Another benefit of this project was the training and involvement of undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary collaboration. At the Woods Hole Oceanographic institution (WHOI), we directly involved undergraduate students in this research, and several graduate students in the WHOI/MIT Joint Program are conducting research based on this project?s foundation. This project also led to new collaborations that will build further on the advances of this research.
